[~accountid:5af5ebc5d7cce75687b9e0f8] [~accountid:63d785b0724a5c79c7b6a308] {{Retimer 2, Channel 7 : reg 0x01: 0x0 No PRBS pattern detected on channel 7 of connector 2 PRBS test FAILED between connector 1, channel 3, and connector 2, channel 7 RCK_to_CBL[4] - CBL_to_RCK[11]: Fail                                           <-- failure, also message sequnces seems different}}Ad look into the discrepancy on messaging why is teh error count not reported in this case?
[~accountid:63d785b0724a5c79c7b6a308] CDR is turned off on fiber tranceivers only, it is not turned off for copper cables, correct?

[~accountid:63d7836c790148a18092c49f] When the PRBS pattern is not detected, like in this case, the software will not try to read the error counters since the test has already failed. My understanding is that the values in the PRBS error counters are meaningless if the checker cannot properly be enabled.
[~accountid:63d785b0724a5c79c7b6a308] perhaps the error counter should indicate N/A is this case?

[~accountid:63d7836c790148a18092c49f] The register write to turn off the CDR (write value 0x00 to byte 98) is done for all cables unconditionally. However this register has no effect on copper cables which don’t have CDR.
[~accountid:63d785b0724a5c79c7b6a308] when we hot swap a cable from copper to optical, do the optical transceivers get programmed as needed?
[~accountid:5af5ebc5d7cce75687b9e0f8] Yes that is done each time you hot plug-in a cable. The programming is the same regardless of the kind of cable.

fields.description:
The vp code programs the re-clockers on the link card to run at 22.5 Gbps when the Spartan version is 1.0.1 or higher (and 25Gbps otherwise).

For fiberoptic link cables we need to re-program the QSFP module (fixed side, on the link card) to work @22.5 Gbps as well.

[~accountid:5cd9e5268ad0f60dca009762] Yes, indeed, I could also reproduce it.

h2. *Update* {{2026-01-21}}

h3. *Preliminary Analysis*

From the relevant tickets [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0666-9171,|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0666-9171,|smart-link]  [[CS0666-6733] REGRESSION | configuration manager does retain but not permanently the source provider value, after reboots happens within 30s of set => value is not sync to storage - Jira|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0666-6733]
it appears that this issue may be caused by one of the following two issues:

{panel:bgColor=#ffebe6}
*Issue 1:* 

a sync mechanism issue in the configurationmanager.apk, meaning the data wasn't written from memory to the file which path {{/data/data/com.barco.clickshare.configurationmanager/files/datastore/clickshare-settings.preferences_pb}} in time.
{panel}

{panel:bgColor=#ffebe6}
*Issue 2:* 

The data sent by XMS and the initialization data from iotagent.apk might overwrite the above configurationmanager.apk's data.
{panel}

Due to the lack of information in the release log, I downloaded version *04.02.01.0017* for testing.

{panel:bgColor=#fffae6}
Attention, I did not connect Duvel to XMS first to eliminate any interference.
{panel}

I tested and captured logs as follows:[^bugreport-Clickshare-Hub-Pro-04.02.01.0017-2026-01-21-09-24-55.zip] 
{color:#ff5630}*Issue 1*{color} has been fixed and has already been merged into the  *04.02.01.0017*  version I tested. [feat: [CS0666-8468] add force flush datastore by vega-chen_Barco · Pull Request #115 · barcoclickshare/configuration-manager-apk|https://github.com/barcoclickshare/configuration-manager-apk/pull/115]

According to the logs below

{noformat}// change enable to false
01-21 08:44:39.568  3354  5137 D ConfigurationProvider: update(clickshare, BaseUnit.Standby.StandbyState, false) from pid: 2544
01-21 08:44:39.568  3354  5137 D ConfigurationProvider: forceFlush is default: true
// change ECO-Mode  to Deep
01-21 08:45:47.297  3354  3986 D ConfigurationProvider: update(clickshare, BaseUnit.Standby.StandbyMode, Deep) from pid: 3202
01-21 08:45:47.297  3354  3986 D ConfigurationProvider: forceFlush is default: true
01-21 08:45:47.327  3354  3986 D ConfigurationProvider: query(clickshare, BaseUnit.Standby.StandbyMode) from pid: 2544
01-21 08:45:47.335  2544  2544 I StandbyManager: Configuration changed for URI: CLICKSHARE_URI, new value: Deep
01-21 08:45:47.335  2544  2544 I StandbyManager: Standby mode changed, current mode = Deep
// change timeout to 1 minute
01-21 08:46:34.516  3354  3986 D ConfigurationProvider: update(clickshare, BaseUnit.Standby.StandbyTime, 1) from pid: 3202
01-21 08:46:34.516  3354  3986 D ConfigurationProvider: forceFlush is default: true
01-21 08:46:34.543  3354  3986 D ConfigurationProvider: query(clickshare, BaseUnit.Standby.StandbyTime) from pid: 2544
01-21 08:46:34.551  2544  2544 I StandbyManager: Configuration changed for URI: CLICKSHARE_URI, new value: 1{noformat}

Then about 1 second later, I exported this file and check it, and found that the values have been correctly synchronized to the file.

{{adb pull /data/data/com.barco.clickshare.configurationmanager/files/datastore/clickshare-settings.preferences_pb}}

Then, restart the device according to the reproduction steps, and the value is correct.

h3. *Next plan:* 

to test this version by connecting it to XMS. If it turns out to be caused by XMS, I will continue to monitor this ticket. [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0666-9171|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0666-9171|smart-link]
Could this be the same issue: [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0666-9171|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0666-9171|smart-link]

h2. *Update* {{2026-02-06}}

Hi [~accountid:61eacaf184311c00694aa230] [~accountid:626a7aba494f170070572e77] 

*So can you use the latest firmware version (for example 04.03.00.master-1438) to verify?*

 this ticket may be caused by the below three issues, you can decide whether to close this duplicate ticket. Thanks

h3. Issue 1: 

The configuration file was not updated in time. If this is the cause, we can mark this ticket as a duplicate of the [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0666-6733|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0666-6733|smart-link] 

h3. Issue 2: 

Setting the timeout to 0, with the iotAgent set to XMS infinite, has already been fixed. We can mark this ticket as a duplicate of the [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0666-9171|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0666-9171|smart-link] 

h3. Issue 3: 

Issues with the twin update. If this is the cause, we can mark this ticket as a duplicate of the [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0062-13506|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0062-13506|smart-link]

Issue was not seen.

See it in the previous comments that I tested also on *master-1361* and there also issue was not reproduced.

I wanted to test with release build since no issue was reported on previous release *04.02.00.0008* with this problem and i supposed it should be fixed in 04.02.01. release.

comments.body:
To review and decide if we will use Permission Groups of bTestWebTools to implement this in BMOP.

!image-20250829-140513.png|width=611,height=681,alt="image-20250829-140513.png"!

[~accountid:63d785e5790148a18092c5b6]  please confirm if:

* BMOP always displays the latest RELEASED WI visible in WASDA, independent form the WI revision at the timing of placing the production order. I believe Christophe informed me that the latest WI opens but a message pops up to inform the operator that there is a mismatch between the revision in the pBOM en de revision in the eBOM
* unreleased version are not visible for the operators in BMOP. Unreleased versions are drafts in WASDA that become visible when selecting “ALL” in  “P-data(in config)”

[~accountid:5a74122a87fdbf2cf0a11c2e] [~accountid:63d78391a5d0c82630686b49] 

* BMOP opens the WI Rev listed in the SAP-ME order BOM for given SFC’s. 
* BMOP informs operators that there is a new WI.REV available and will be used for new orders on same P/N.
* The shopfloor operator, line supervisor, line responsible can decide and have the flexibility to already use the new WI in case this is the better option (WI ER = apply from next order)   
* In case WI Rev must change than ER need to be PRIO apply on all open orders and next = abort & recall open SAP-ME orders and regenerate the order BOM



Hi Lisbeth,

Is there already an acceptance from the planner to regenerate the orders when WI must change on open running orders?

Input Quality is clear: BMOP ALWAYS needs to open the latest +released+ revision. If not possible, BMOP at least should provide a pop-up where the operator has the +possibility to select the option to open the latest RELEASED revision+

# yes there is a pop-up the case of WI Rev difference between new orders, and running orders of same material to process, the operator have the +possibility to select the option to open the latest RELEASED revision+. 
# The operator has also the possiblity to add SAP-comments to the SFC flogging why there was a need to switch to another WI version. 
# We can also add in data collect a Concession number to document that another WI Rev was needed or why we had deviated from the WI part of order BOM. 

A few examples of GUI:

!image-20251010-081140.png|width=1261,alt="image-20251010-081140.png"!



!image-20251010-081213.png|width=1246,alt="image-20251010-081213.png"!



!image-20251010-081247.png|width=601,alt="image-20251010-081247.png"!

!image-20251010-081816.png|width=1233,alt="image-20251010-081816.png"!

!image-20251010-081840.png|width=1233,alt="image-20251010-081840.png"!

Be informed: 

the feature request “Approval should be in the form of a badge action by a person with the appropriate function” is on the BMOP backlog it is not scheduled forY25.

Prio is given to BMOP data collect, BMOP.NET MQTT requests for Doka automation
x

Implementation details from BMOP wiki:

h2. Default document

When starting an SFC in BMOP a document viewer is showed with a list of documents found in the BOM, one document gets selected as the default. The default document is selected by going through the following criteria until a match is found:

* It walks the routing in reverse, starting from the current routing step, then the previous routing step and so on until the first routing step.
** The first work instruction document for this routing step where the document part number starts with the product part number.
** The first work instruction document for this routing step.
** The first document for this routing step.
* The first document where the document part number starts with the product part number.
* The first document.

h2. Revisions

The default document revision is the revision that is defined in the shop order BOM. If a {{REV_CHANGE}} _Data Collection_ was logged on the SFC, the plant BOM for this material/revision is used instead. The operator can switch between documents and can see the list of available document revisions. Some revisions have annotations:

* {{Current Revision}}: The latest released revision.
* {{Order Revision}}: The revision defined in the BOM.
* {{Not Released}}: An unreleased revision.

h2. Changing revisions

!image-20260210-131120.png|width=1069,alt="image-20260210-131120.png"!

When changing between document revisions an authorization is required.

* If the document revision has been released, the operator needs to give a motivation text as to why this revision is selected and can use their badge to submit. 
!change-doc-rev-released.gif|width=497,alt="change-doc-rev-released.gif"!
* If the document revision has not been released, the badge from a PEI engineer, line supervisor or product supervisor is required in addition to the motivation text. The authorizer can select the scope of the authorization:
** SFC: This document revision can be used for this SFC.
** Shop Order: This document revision can be used for the entire shop order.
** Material: This document revision can be used for a specified quantity of products with this part number. 
!change-doc-rev-unreleased.gif|width=434,alt="change-doc-rev-unreleased.gif"!

The authorization is stored locally on the PC and is logged as a non-conformity in SAP with the following data:

* Sfc: The serial number
* Operation: The SAP operation
* Resource: The SAP resource as defined in the BMOP configuration
* Non-Conformity code: {{ILR_DOCU}}
* Initials: the initials of the BMOP user
* Artnr: the part number of the document
* Fault description: depends on if it's a released or unreleased document revision:

{noformat}BMOP: The operator has opted to use document '<document material>' revision '<document revision>' instead of '<BOM document revision>' with the stated reason:
<motivation>{noformat}

{noformat}BMOP: The operator has opted to use unreleased document '<document material>' revision '<document revision>' instead of '<BOM document revision>', authorized by <authorizer initials>, with the stated reason:
<motivation>{noformat}

* Repair: {{N/A}}
* Fault assignment: {{OPS_ASSEMBLY}}

If the authorization is cancelled, the viewer stays on the currently selected document revision, no non-conformity is created.

!change-doc-rev-cancelled.gif|width=410,alt="change-doc-rev-cancelled.gif"!

Dag Giel,

Top design documentatie initiatief.

Ik zie nog niet de info op de Wiki, maar dit komt waarschijnlijk straks wel zichtbaar ...

fields.description: During an audit it was noticed that the operators could switch to unreleased workinstructions in BMOP. This should not be possible. The operators should always be presented with the latest released and approved workinstruction. Switching to an unreleased and thus a not approved version of the workinstructions should only be possible with approval from: Line Responsible, Line Supervisor or PEI engineer. This is needed to enable training during early stages of the NPI process. Approval should be in the form of a badge action by a person with the appropriate function.

fields.description:
* Kortrijk revamp plan is to start (April) using “Classic Kanban” on workplaces with BMOP instead of the event driven Kanban (based on control cycle scanning). 
* The classic Kanban trigger will be based on a operator scanning of Kanban barcode. The value scanned = KANBANID number extended with digit 2 (=KANBANID>+2)
* A Mulesoft REST AÏ will be designed by SWIT available end FEB
* Mulesoft API will give error message back when API is called to many times in function of maximum defined kanban BINs (like max 3 BINs). Good to show this to operator (“max bin requests exceeded - Mxx material kanban al ready in request)

Orginal schedule request: 

* Revamp planning:
** Fase 1: Netwerking start 7/04/26
** Fase 2: SA + FA
** Fase 3: Cleanroom + rest

comments.body: [~accountid:5cd9795c3b428d0dcd7c5094] , do you have any comment?

Thanks for the previous investigation.

In the current “dw-hdmi.c“ workflow, the "can't get cec wake up irq" error is handled gracefully. 
However, I agree that we should add the second interrupt to the DTS file to prevent the crash during the boot sequence.

Let’s include the wakeup IRQ in the DTS as shown below to verify if it resolves the issue:

File: arch/arm64/boot/dts/rockchip/rk3399.dtsi

{noformat}interrupts = <GIC_SPI 23 IRQ_TYPE_LEVEL_HIGH 0>,
             <GIC_SPI 24 IRQ_TYPE_LEVEL_HIGH 0>; // Index 1: CEC Wakeup
{noformat}

[~accountid:5cd9795c3b428d0dcd7c5094] Thanks for the update. I think adding CEC Wakeup interrupt to the DTS is an appropriate improvement for dw-hdmi driver, however maybe we should have some further investigation on the *root cause* and the *use cases* that cause *__report_bad_irq* for irq 64.

As per the /proc/interrupts file of CX-M, irq 64 is currently used by both *ff940000.hdmi* and *dw-hdmi-cec*, hence there might be an issue with handling of {{dw_hdmi_hardirq}} (from {{dw-hdmi.c}}) or {{dw_hdmi_cec_hardirq}} (from {{dw-hdmi-cec.c}}).

{noformat}$ cat /proc/interrupts | grep 64
 64:       7207          0          0          0          0          0     GICv3  55 Level     ff940000.hdmi, dw-hdmi-cec{noformat}

In addition, this issue happens rarely (sometimes in system test). Maybe we can firstly check some related use cases (HDMI/CEC) that could reproduce the issue manually or a convenient way to get more log (debug log) from dw-hdmi driver, that will give more hints to confirm the root cause.

Summary:

# *Issue*: log shows kernel backtrace *___report_bad_irq_*: *irq 64* is disabled due to a lot of unhandled interrupt signals on it.
# *Occurrence*: till now seems only occurs *rarely at 1st sec when booting* CX-M Taishan in system test, not sure how to reproduce it manually.
# *Affected features*: *irq 64* on CX-M is currently shared between *ff940000.hdmi* driver and *dw-hdmi-cec* driver; so, when this issue happens, *irq 64* is disabled, the assumption is that *HDMI* and *CEC Wakeup* functionalities will then not work anymore (until reboot?).
# *Root cause*: There should be issue in either {{dw_hdmi_hardirq}} (from {{dw-hdmi.c}}) or {{dw_hdmi_cec_hardirq}} (from {{dw-hdmi-cec.c}}), which causes a lot of unhandled interrupt signals.
# *Next step*: we can consider 2 approaches:
## Still let *ff940000.hdmi* driver and *dw-hdmi-cec* driver share same *irq 64*. Then try to *reproduce the issue manually* and get more debug log to determine if the issue comes from {{dw_hdmi_hardirq}}or {{dw_hdmi_cec_hardirq}}, then fix it. Need to list down cases of *HDMI* and *CEC Wakeup* functionalities to try. May take a lot of efforts.
## Firstly, *add an IRQ index 1 to rk3399.dtsi* to have *ff940000.hdmi* driver and *dw-hdmi-cec* driver on different IRQs (this should be a good improvement). Then monitoring the system test output next to see if issue actually comes from *ff940000.hdmi* or *dw-hdmi-cec*. After that we can investigate effectively on that one particular *driver hardirq function*. Also, we need to consider impact of adding this new IRQ index.
To build a new SDK/FW for the 2nd approach in previous comment (add an *IRQ index 1* to *rk3399.dtsi*) and test it locally first.
New SDK/FW for the change is ready. Now doing a code-walkthrough study to understand/cover which CEC-wakeup features will be impacted.

+*New finding:*+ the improvement “Adding an *IRQ index 1* to *rk3399.dtsi*“ should be done in another ticket, since it may not fix the “*___report_bad_irq_*: *irq 64*” of this ticket. Details:

# There are currently 3 drivers related to *synopsys dw-hdmi*: *ff940000.hdmi*, *dw-hdmi-cec* and *cec-wakeup*:
([cstp-msi-rockchip-kernel/drivers/gpu/drm/bridge/synopsys at v5.10.198-rk3399-linux-17 · barcoclickshare/cstp-msi-rockchip-kernel|https://github.com/barcoclickshare/cstp-msi-rockchip-kernel/tree/v5.10.198-rk3399-linux-17/drivers/gpu/drm/bridge/synopsys])
## *ff940000.hdmi* and *dw-hdmi-cec* are currently matching to *irq 64*, so the issue “*___report_bad_irq_*: *irq 64*” is caused by only either *ff940000.hdmi* or *dw-hdmi-cec*.
## *cec-wakeup* are currently failed to initialize, since it expects to match with *irq 65*, but we face “missing *IRQ index 1* in *rk3399.dtsi*” observation. This would cause another issue, not “*___report_bad_irq_*: *irq 64*” and should be fixed in another ticket.
# To check which driver causes this issue, we need to check which one of *ff940000.hdmi* or *dw-hdmi-cec* driver (or both?) fail to handle the interrupt signals on *irq 64*.

+*Next step:*+ Build a new SDK/FW that prints number of times *ff940000.hdmi* and *dw-hdmi-cec* fail to handle interrupt signals and test this SDK/FW with *CX-M Taishan* device to narrow down the suspicious area.

*Update:* Added log to prints number of times *ff940000.hdmi* or *dw-hdmi-cec* driver fail to handle the interrupt signals on *irq 64*. Tried it on system_test *CX-M* and see that issue is at *ff940000.hdmi (*99988 unhandled_irq over total 100881*)*:
{color:#0747a6}(In general: An irq line is deemed "stuck" and disabled ({color}{color:#0747a6}*___report_bad_irq_*{color}{color:#0747a6}) if {color}{color:#0747a6}*99,900 of the last 100,000 IRQ events*{color}{color:#0747a6} were unhandled—i.e., {color}{{unhandled}}{color:#0747a6} ≥ 99,900){color}

*Next step:* This show issue in hardirq handling {{dw_hdmi_hardirq}} of *ff940000.hdmi*. To check further any issue in that function and which use-case (from system_test) can trigger this.

*Update:* Till now, as the issue is only seen at *1st sec of startup*, it is a hint that one cause might be {{dw_hdmi_init_hw}} is called after {{devm_request_threaded_irq}}in *dw-hdmi.c*, which causes this instability. Furthermore, refer to *mainstream Linux 5.12 and latest master branch*, it is shown that {{dw_hdmi_init_hw}} should be called before {{devm_request_threaded_irq}}.

*Next step:* Add change to call {{dw_hdmi_init_hw}} before {{devm_request_threaded_irq}}, then build new SDK/FW and run *system_test* for it on *CX-M*.

Set priority to P2 since it appears frequently.

comments.body:
Just had a session with Jean-Luc and someone from Engineering (i.e. Nikolaj). Just giving a summary over here.

# The troublesome address 10.238.208.56 has no entry in the IPMC table according to 
## `j h p b s 1 u 0 "ipmc table show"`
# It was also seen from snooping that there were cache misses and entries get dropped:
## {noformat}show log coun all occurred 
show log coun ipmc occurred 
show log coun ipmc occurred | i iss
conf log fil def ad ev IPMC.Snoop.l3CacheMiss
show log coun ipmc occurred | i iss
conf log fil def ad ev IPMC.Snoop.l2CacheMiss 
...
show mcast cache 239.208.3.56 

Snooping/MVR Cache Timeout: 300 sec 

 Type Group             Sender               Age  InVlan 

pim   239.208.3.56      10.238.208.13        0    vlan208
      Vlan             Port        Vid  
      vlan208          3           208  
                       23          208  

Multicast cache distribution:
     2 entries from Snooping           0 entries from MVR         166 entries from PIM


Total Cache Entries: 168{noformat}
## {noformat}show pim cache detail
show igmp snooping detail
show igmp snooping
show mcast cache summary
j h p b s 1 u 0 "ipmc table show"
show log | i rr{noformat}
This last command `show log | i rr` showed, amongst others, the following interesting line:
{noformat}10/07/2025 17:37:48.90 <Erro:HAL.IPv4Mc.L3TblFull> IPv4 multicast entry not added. Hardware L3 Table full. (Logged at most once per hour.){noformat}

What Extreme is going to investigate:

* Why the address is not in the IPMC table
* Why the cache is full
* Why the cache collision happens
* How to prevent cache collisions in the future. Some proposals, but further investigation needed:
** Hash-recursion level
** lookup-key
** etc.

From this session it also became clear that we also need to evaluate something:

The following command showed that there is a limitation inn the hash table size. This means that there is a limit on how many multicast streams can be supported by this switch. This switch has a hash table limit of 256. Currently there are 164 used (i.e. 64%). So this raises the question, how many streams must be supported? And also evaluate the use(fulness) of the streams currently used. An analysis must be performed. Therefore I will plan a session with Geert en Wauter.

{noformat}show ipr reserved-entries statistics
                                      |-----In HW Route Table-----|  |--------In HW L3 Hash Table-------|
                                       # Used Routes   # IPv4 Hosts   IPv4   IPv4   IPv6    IPv4    IPv6
Slot  Type                              IPv4   IPv6    Local Remote   Local  Rem.   Local   MCast   MCast
----  ------------------------------- ------- ------  ------ ------  ------ ------  -----  ------  ------
1     5120-24X-4Y                           4      0      16      0      10      0      0     164       0

Theoretical maximum for each resource type:
X435                                       32     16      64     64     509   4096    509 *  2048 *  1024
4120, 5120                                 64     32      64     64     509    512    256 *   256 *   128
X440G2                                    480    240     512    512    1021   4096   1021 *  2048 *  1024
4220, 5320-24T-4X-XT                      992    496    1024   1024    4096   4096   2048 *  2048 *  1024
5320-16P-2MXT-2X                          992    496    1024   1024    4093   8192   4093 *  4096 *  2048
5320-16P-4XE, 5320 24-port except XT     8160   4080    8192   8192   14334  16384   8192 *  8192 *  4096
5320 48-port, 5420F                     12256   6128   12285  12288   14334  16384   8192 *  8192 *  4096

X460G2-16MP                             16352   8176   16384  16384   73726  81920  40960 * 40960 * 20480
5720MW                                  16352   8176   16384  16384   94206 163840  24573 * 81920 * 40960

5720MXW                                 24544  12272   24576  24576  208894 294912 122877 *147456 * 73728
X695                                    32736  16368   32768  32768  167934 278528  57341 *139264 * 69632
7520, 7720                              32736  16368   32768  32768  167934 278528  57341 *139264 * 69632{noformat}



Log files of the held session for reference:

[^20251009_110328_10.238.208.1_putty.log]
[^20251009_100212_10.238.208.1_putty.log]

*Analysis*

The Extreme switch parallel active multicast count is including the SAP multicast (src ip address, mc ip address) pairs. So this switch has 28 ports, this means 256/28 = 9 parallel active mc streams per dongle. A scenario of 1 interface of an MNA440:

* 1 mDNS ^(1)
* 1 SAP: 224.2.127.254
* 1 Audio
* 1 < x < 2, x for 4K video: 4K is on 2 interfaces, so that's still less than 2 components per interface.

This means about *5 out of 9* parallel mc streams of the interface are taken. This is without taking inter-or or NMS into account. For these the following need to be considered:

* 239.192.100.100 --> NMS announcement
* 239.255.255.250 --> DHCP?  Lijkt verzonden te worden door hosts met auto-ip
* 239.249.0.100 --> NMS InterOR (maar dus enkel subscribed door NMS)

This means 8 out of 9 possible streams would be taken in the case of only MNA440s.

Note that in reality, the switch will function in a building (hospital) with multiple rooms (ORs), for which the switch will have an entry for (source address of other OR, mc address) pairs for SAP. From the example down below it becomes clear that *the usage of the SAP protocol will be a limiting scaling factor.*

*To give an example*

In the 208 setup NMS was switched off and the dongles were rebooted. This will result into these multicast entries being removed. It was seen that about 130 of 256 entries were still there and these were all SAP entries from the other ORs. So in a large setup (i.e. with multiple ORs the usage of the SAP protocol will be a limiting scaling factor of the setup/building/hospital.

(1): Actually, the mDNS is not counted as an entry by Extreme, which is something curious.

[^mcast_addresses_usage.txt]

Today we ran our test and hit the same issue within an hour. The situation is as follows.

h1. Summarised description of components

h2. PCIe card

The PCIe card MNA-180 consists of 4 network ethernet interfaces (0 1, 2, 3), referred to as NIC.
This card serves as a video generator and receiver.
The ENC (resp. DEC) of the PCIe acts as a TX (resp. RX) in the PCIe and get received on (transmitted from) the switch its RX (resp. TX).

h2. MNA-420 decoder dongle

An MNA-420 DECoder dongle consists of 1 network interface.
It is a DEC which means it decodes packets to convert them to video output.
This DEC will subscribe on the MCADDR of the video stream it needs to receive to perform decoding.

h1. Minimised working situation description

{noformat}device    device_eth_port    MAC                  switch_port
MNA-180   0                  00:04:A5:41:0A:B6    3
MNA-180   1                  00:04:A5:41:0A:B7    4
MNA-180   2                  00:04:A5:41:0A:B8    1
MNA-180   3                  00:04:A5:41:0A:B9    2
MNA-420   0                  00:04:a5:51:28:69    7{noformat}

On this PCIe card are 2 ENCoders (ENClat1 and ENClat2) and 2 DECoders (DEClat1 and DEClat2) defined.
The PCIe is streaming a FHD (1920x1080) p60 video stream (bandwith of 2985 Mbps) with ENClat1 on MCADDR 239.208.0.253 on NIC0.
The PCIe is subscribed with DEClat2 on MCADDR 239.208.0.253 on NIC1.
Also a MNA-420 DECoder is subscribed on MCADDR 239.208.0.253 on its ethernet port 0.

h1. Analysis

h2. MNA-420

On this MNA-420 DEC, that needs to receive the stream, the following symptom was observed again in the logs:

{noformat}"RxPacketsLost": 79894839,
"RxPacketsReceived": 2544143,
"SequenceNumber": 84724550,{noformat}

On the PCIe the following analysis was performed based on its logs

{noformat}definition    MCADDR           NIC    slot    Bandwidth [Mbps]    image    Note
DEClat1       239.208.0.111    1      1       2985                full
DEClat2       239.208.0.253    1      0       2985                full --> high packet loss
ENClat1       239.208.0.253    0      0       2980                full
ENClat2       239.208.0.254    0      1       2980                full{noformat}

Interfaces & expected bandwidth (*from perspective of PCIe* for rx/tx)(^1):

{noformat}
                      |     EXPECTED BASED ON PCIE    |  ACTUAL REPORTED BY SWITCH |
PCIE_NIC    SW_PORT   |RX_BW [Mbps]    TX_BW [Mbps]   |RX_BW [Mbps]    TX_BW [Mbps]|
0           3          0               2980+2980=5960  0               5477
1           4          2985+2985=5970  0               2843            0
2           1          0               0               0               0
3           2          0               0               0               0{noformat}

The receiving MNA-420 is connected to port 7 and should only be receiving the single stream at 239.208.0.253, with a bandwidth of 2985 Mbps.
However, we’re only seeing the switch transmit around 780 Mbps on that port.
Wich is also observed on the PCIe DEC subscribed to that stream which only receives 239.208.0.111 and not 239.208.0.253 resulting in only 2843 Mbps and not 5970 Mbps.

In the attachment you can find the tech-support output from the Putty window.

Currently our setup (i.e. 208) is kept in this state for further investigation by Extreme.

[^20251010_111111_10.238.208.1_putty.log]

Yesterday call with Extreme:

Last night, they were supposed to gather more information from Engineering, and today they are expected to share their findings with us.

On our side, we need to investigate whether certain entries can be excluded from the hash table. To achieve this, I’m exploring the possibility of adding policies.

Yesterday they mentioned that the hash table should not exceed 75% of its maximum capacity. Since the maximum is 256 entries, that means it should be limited to 192 entries to allow for a buffer. They also said they would confirm with Engineering whether this applies also to our specific model, and were supposed to get back to us today.

Just finished a call with Jean-Luc. He aligns with my reasoning and also finds the advice regarding CRC16 rather odd. He will relay this feedback to the Engineering team. In the meantime, he recalled why the focus was on “configuration changes or traffic engineering.” Apparently, during the alpha or beta phases, a similar issue was observed, and at that time, the solution involved configuring a policy. That’s exactly what I’m currently working on, so it seems like a valid path to continue exploring.

Alignment/Assessment sessie met Geert en Wouter:

* OPTIE 1: SAP weglaten OF iets implementeren/configuren zodat dit zo goed als mogelijk wordt weggelaten (bv. TTL op 1 zetten, of iets anders dat extreme voorziet om te laten expiren) zodat de SAPs van de andere ORs gedropt worden → vermijden dat (source_ip, mcast_ip)-paren de hash tabel opvullen:
** in Nexxis2.0, kan dit want wordt daar niet meer gebruikt
** in Nexxis1.18, is dit inherent aan de werkwijze. Dit zou een te grote aanpassing zijn om in een mogelijk volgende 1.18 release (1.18.10?) te steken, want dit zou een groot stuk van 2.0 zijn en ook vragen stellen rond oude devices MNA-120. → te grote wijziging → switch releasen met als note dan niet gebruiken voor inter-or bij 1.18?
* OTPIE2: toevoegen van een prefilter in de switch configuratie, waarbij de (source_ip, SAP-mcast)-paren worden geprefilterd zodat deze niet in de hash tabel terechtkomen en deze streams door de CPU worden afgehandeld. Dit zou normaal het aantal entries verminderen, zodat er zo veel mogelijk ruimte is voor video streams in de tabel. Dit is een valide optie voor de afhandeling door de CPU want de (source_ip, SAP-mcast)-paren
** nemen het meest plaats in;
** zijn tegelijk ook een van de lagere-bandbreedte streams;
** hun gebruik is gespreid in de tijd.

[~accountid:557058:7ad3acfd-4cb1-4b56-9f45-cb7dc5cf7769] Due to me going on holiday for a week, I tag you in this itrack I maintain. I have taken notes about everything on this bug. So if there would be any updates during my leave, could you please maintain this itrack during my leave?
Kind regards
Andreas

Hi [~accountid:557058:7ad3acfd-4cb1-4b56-9f45-cb7dc5cf7769], need to assign this to you. Right before my holiday we successfully added the filter to the switch and observed a huge drop in entries in the table. As our system tests on the 208 setup have not picked up the original issue anymore during my holiday, it seems like this might be a possible fix. We talked about testing the switch in Nexxis 1.18 before my holiday, but due to a shift in priorities this topic went to the background. What is the status right now on this switch?
It was talked about the filter being added to the switch configurator, any update about this?

With flooding of the SAP multicast group (so handling it as broadcast instead of multicast), it seems the problem we had is solved, but whether it will also work if that switch is used as a central switch is completely unclear. The cause of all the misery seems to be that at Extreme (I get the impression that their development has moved to India) PIM is only supported in combination with SSM, and if you want to use SSM, you need to check the source IP for each subscription, and that therefore has to go into the hardware hash tables. And because they don’t support PIM-SM without SSM, you have to choose: either locally on the switch use only IGMP V2 with a hardware hash table that only contains multicast groups (or MAC addresses), but then you don’t have upstream multicast routing, or enable PIM, but then you run into problems with multicast groups that need to be routed and can have multiple sources, because then for each of those sources



A meeting is planned with Extreme to discuss to remove the PIM SSM feature.

We have agreed with Extreme to have an extra command, so that we can enable to exclude SAP messages out of the HAL table. This way we can avoid the HAL table becoming full. This new firmware should be available by mid-January.

We have also agreed to describe the method to exclude multicast addresses from the HAL table. This might be handy for an integrator to exclude low-bandwidth multicast traffic from the HAL table.

Currently verifying the pre-GPA FW received from extreme, which is put here: [https://bin.barco.com/artifactory/dior-release/NexxisOR-2.0-ER-04-4501/components/extreme_5120-33.5.2.118-patch2-1.xos|https://bin.barco.com/artifactory/dior-release/NexxisOR-2.0-ER-04-4501/components/extreme_5120-33.5.2.118-patch2-1.xos]

Currently the verification is ongoing. This is taking a long time. Therefore giving an overview here of what has been done with the pre-GPA release (not official, going to explicitly stress this again)

# On the original 208 setup on which the issue was observed, the issue was reproduced with the original 33.4.1.15 version of the switch. The applied test.pol policy was removed. This was successfully reproduced. → Sanity test for ground truth. Took 23 hours from start of test cycle continuously performing the {{test_tearing_uhd_and_fhd_pip}} to reproduce the issue and break (stop) in this state + some time to analyse PCIe and switch logs + stats.
# On this 208 setup the new switch version was installed. A {{test_tearing_uhd_and_fhd_pip}} test cycle has started to break in the issue state. Took about 11 - 12 hours from start + time to analyse. → Issue can be reproduced without running the requested commands. So this gives us again a reference that without any special config, the behaviour between the 33.4.1.15 and the 33.5.2.118-patch2-1 is similar for this.
# Next step was to apply the specified commands to resemble the used test.pol file:
{noformat}configure igmp snooping flood-list add group 239.249.0.100
configure igmp snooping flood-list add group 239.192.100.100
configure igmp snooping flood-list add group 224.2.127.254{noformat}
# Now the multicast subscriptions were left and rejoined, rerouting using the NMS API.
# Finally the the {{test_tearing_uhd_and_fhd_pip}} cycle will be rerun to see whether this issue will reoccur again.
So this final rerun of the {{test_tearing_uhd_and_fhd_pip}} is ongoing.

The test has been running for 24h and not triggered a break.
The stats of the hal ipv4mc also appear to be OK, example snapshot down below:

HI [~accountid:63f3326cc1685a24e1304faa], 

I don’t see the need for a group address range.

We can ask if this would work, but I would stick to the current implementation.

[~accountid:557058:7ad3acfd-4cb1-4b56-9f45-cb7dc5cf7769] Ok, thanks for the clarification. It was something that caught my eye. I have asked them if it is possible, as they stated the command is in a PoC and open for changes.
I share your opinion, given the push for the current deadline.
Extreme’s statement that that the command is open for changes, gives me the feeling that - if this “range” feature is not present already - it would be possible for them to add this is in a future release. But this is just a feeling. First, let’s wait for their response for the existence of this range.

fields.customfield_10041:
* Operate Nexxis setup with MNA-440 dongles and PCIe decoder connected via Extreme 5120-24X-4Y switch.
* Run automated overnight tests without rebooting the switch. From experience it was deducted that the tearing 4K with FHD test appears (i.e. {{test_tearing_uhd_and_fhd_pip}}) to catch the problem more easily.
* Observe:
** Packet loss on multicast video streams (e.g., 239.208.2.66) in the logs be observed as {{lost-video-packets}} at PCIe and `RxPacketsLost` at MNA dongle side.
** mDNS traffic loss on 224.0.0.251 (port 5353), not received by NMS2.
* Attempt recovery by restarting dongles, NMS2, and PCs – issue persists.
* Reboot switch – issue resolved (is not a solution)

comments.body: [~accountid:557058:8cc0ce43-3d92-4079-909a-a49cb1b9c5e3] I have included a video showing the error and a mail with additional details provided by the person facing the issue while using the API for the Milestone VMS integration.

[~accountid:557058:8cc0ce43-3d92-4079-909a-a49cb1b9c5e3] [~accountid:640f05acb05b4e3e7da841d8]  Is there an update on this defect? A good workaround? The Milestone integration must be deployed by end of February.
[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] I could not start investigation till now. Assigning to [~accountid:712020:80043fb7-3f11-45c2-bafe-daf06b4ca79d] as discussed in standup.

[~accountid:712020:80043fb7-3f11-45c2-bafe-daf06b4ca79d] The issue does not happen with short camera names. With ‘longer’ names, it happens. I tested using a ‘very long’ name and then it fails alwyas. Could there be a ‘range’ of name lengths that sometimes fails and sometimes works?

What is the maximum supported and validated length of a source name?
In the video, the below name fails with error 500. 

!image-20260205-072157.png|width=489,alt="image-20260205-072157.png"!

In the meantime I checked and it seems the length is max. 50. Above I see the same error as mentioned in this ticket. Below, I cannot reproduce the issue.

[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] you are right the max length that we have is of 50 Character i can confirm this as i checked on UI as well only 50 charcters are allowed . But i see that validation part is missing at the API level implementation hence the API call breaks if long names are given . If required we can add the length level check at API level as well that would return you with appropriate error message .Please confirm the next course of action 
cc [~accountid:640f05acb05b4e3e7da841d8]  [~accountid:557058:85b9f1e1-a89e-4572-99ed-838906d54129]

[~accountid:712020:80043fb7-3f11-45c2-bafe-daf06b4ca79d] Having descriptive error messages in both the UX and DX (Developer Experience) is important for the general appreciation of a product. So yes, a reply that tells that the name is too long, surely helps a developer.

Note, this does not explain the 50% succes rate as stated in the title of this work item but that might be not correct. Then it is: longer than 50 always fails, shorter than 50 never fails. I will check with the API developer and ping back.

I looked in the API documentation of the parameters and did not find a description of the limitations of each parameter too.

[~accountid:712020:80043fb7-3f11-45c2-bafe-daf06b4ca79d] Notice that in the video, the source name was considerably longer than 50 characters and the creation was successful. That’s why it was not clear that there is a limitation. Names that can be created via the API:

* test manual bfbcd266-a7b5-48cf-8601-17685f4890f2 camera src payload
* aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa aaaaaaaaaaaaaa
* {{aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaab}}

Name that cannot be created via the API

* test123 test123 test123 test te1s23 test123 test123

It is strange that creating long names sometimes works and sometimes does not work.

[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] i have added the fix so that now the UI and API call would have same response PFA the snapshot. This should fix the issue


!image-20260206-070513.png|width=1114,alt="image-20260206-070513.png"!

[~accountid:712020:80043fb7-3f11-45c2-bafe-daf06b4ca79d] Nice. That will prevent a few more tickets like this in the future 🙂 .

Although this is just enforcing what is ‘the rule’ I recommend to include this in the release notes of the CTRL version this will be in. That’s 1.14 is suppose. There is a small chance that if somebody has written an integration that successfully creates sources with the ‘illegal name length’, this integrations will suddenly break. With the amount of CTRL systems growing in the world, the likelihood of similar situations only increases, making the mentioning of such changes in the release notes increasingly important. Thanks!
[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] Intellicene has an integration that creates cameras, so they could be affected.

[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] [~accountid:640f05c9c35660c269b9613f] Just to inform that this limit of 50 Characters is applicable to all type(Encoder,Web,Camera,RDP) of source name . I will check with intigration team to check if they are creating any source name which has more than 50 charcaters length.

[~accountid:712020:80043fb7-3f11-45c2-bafe-daf06b4ca79d]For other sources that cameras there is no risk that this would affect 3rd party API developpers as the calls to create these are not public yet. So catched just in time to avoid trouble. [~accountid:640f05acb05b4e3e7da841d8] I propose the following: mention in the 1.13 release notes that the maximum length of 50 chars will be enforced in the API from 1.14 onwards. That is a great example of Barco proactively informing its customers and giving them more time to adapt their integrations.

[~accountid:712020:80043fb7-3f11-45c2-bafe-daf06b4ca79d] the screenshot here is of v0. the v1 component test has different sets of error message, which is not very descriptive
[https://github.com/barcoemu/ocs-ctrl-source-service/pull/402/changes#diff-f9a4d83dd3385886eaca6e3efa4a48157f137b79fc8c7edef0fb6f109a1ef05cR607-R615|https://github.com/barcoemu/ocs-ctrl-source-service/pull/402/changes#diff-f9a4d83dd3385886eaca6e3efa4a48157f137b79fc8c7edef0fb6f109a1ef05cR607-R615] 
[https://github.com/barcoemu/ocs-ctrl-source-service/pull/402/changes#diff-f9a4d83dd3385886eaca6e3efa4a48157f137b79fc8c7edef0fb6f109a1ef05cR554-R558|https://github.com/barcoemu/ocs-ctrl-source-service/pull/402/changes#diff-f9a4d83dd3385886eaca6e3efa4a48157f137b79fc8c7edef0fb6f109a1ef05cR554-R558] 
Please provide the correct screenshot for error message.

[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] Also based on note from [~accountid:640f05c9c35660c269b9613f] , since we are adding this validation, does it impact any customer who is using the v1 configure API’s?

cc [~accountid:61fb7f9bb3ec760068c222e7] [~accountid:557058:d62807bc-ead8-4dd3-a387-0d271329117c] please note this change for v1 api’s
[~accountid:63d782ddf1475ad42c575a89]Is the name length restriction somewhere documented already? If so then a KB can have an explanation of the API feedback of a name is too long.

comments.body: Tested on v1.00.00B01 that reconnecting the HDMI cable is still unable to wake up the display from power saving mode.

The power consumption is 14W immediately after entering sleep mode, and drops to approximately 1.016W after a few minutes. It still fails to meet the requirement of less than 0.3W, and the device cannot be woken up after entering sleep mode.
The power consumption is 0.6W(greater than spec 0.5W) after entering sleep mode on v1.00.00B05 version.

Check the test result on MDAC-8732 MDY by using the latest firmware v1.00.00T01.

Observation:

# The power consumption is 0.52W(greater than spec 0.5W) after entering sleep mode on v1.00.00T01 version.

So I think this issue has not been fixed. so re-open the ticket.

comments.body:
I used the runs of date 09/01/26 available at :
[https://mx.barco.com:4800/tests_details?id_list=[104824066]|https://mx.barco.com:4800/tests_details?id_list=%5B104824066%5D]

But this process can be done using any other failing job

h2. Main process

Compare the Jenkins full console logs compared to the server journalctl logs to find issues.
A log line in Jenkins dates the start of the journalctl, use it to synchronize the timestamps of the Jenkins console and the journalctl to match events (see screenshot timestamp).

h2. On Jenkins

A normal run can be identified with : 

* First, a short burst of altMode.state="readyToShare"
* Then, one altMode.state="sharing"
* Then, checking unshare
See screenshots of iteration 2 for more details.

A wrong run can be identified with : 

* A very long burst of altMode.state="readyToShare", 
* with no switch to sharing
* "failed" keyword
See screenshots of iteration 4 for more details.

Jenkins alone doesn't allow to draw conclusions on the bug.

h2. On the journalctl

The journalctl logs can be hard to read.
*Use the "parse_logs.py" script to extract 2 files :*

* report.txt : a minimal version of the relevant dp-alt-mode event logs
* anomalies.txt : a report of all the wrong dp-alt-mode runs found in the logs

A normal iteration should have the following pattern : 

* Button press
* Sharing request
* Volatile sharing request
* Volatile sharing
* Sharing
* Button press
* Unsharing request
* Volatile sharing unrequest
* Volatile unsharing
* Unsharing

Any iteration not matching is flagged as an "anomaly"

h2. Conclusion

We find that _almost_ all anomalies have the same structure :

Timestamp: XXX - Wrong event: Expected 'Sharing', got 'Volatile unsharing'
Timestamp: XXX - Wrong event: Expected 'button press', got 'Sharing'
Timestamp: XXX - Wrong event: Expected 'button press', got 'Unshare request'
Timestamp: XXX - Wrong event: Expected 'button press', got 'Volatile sharing unrequest'

*See report.txt, what happens is that an unknown "Volatile unsharing" spawns in between a "Volatile sharing" and a "Sharing".*
Therefore, the dp-alt-mode fallbacks instantly from "Sharing" to "Unshare request" without any button press, meaning it's not sharing when the cx_system_test tries to read state from dp-alt-mode, so the test is stuck

*What we need to investigate further is why this unknown 'Volatile unsharing' happens.*
And maybe other type of anomalies that can be found.



[^journal-button.txt]
[^report.txt]
[^parse-logs.py]
[^anomalies.txt]

!timestamp-set.png|width=654,alt="timestamp-set.png"!

!iteration-2-start.png|width=654,alt="iteration-2-start.png"!

!iteration-2-end.png|width=654,alt="iteration-2-end.png"!

!iteration-4-start.png|width=654,alt="iteration-4-start.png"!

!iteration-4-end.png|width=654,alt="iteration-4-end.png"!

*The unknown "Volatile unsharing" comes from an unsharing trigger caused by a screen error.*

See the logs : each “unknown Volatile unsharing" comes after the compositor handling a “Removed from screen” error : 

{noformat}Jan 09 00:05:42.232830 ButtonGen5-001200602423 buttongen5-daemon-dp-alt-mode[1630]: [DEBUG] [ffff92fdec40] [UnifiedProtocol] [handleShareSourceReply]: In function

Now we need to understand why this error is triggered

When looking at the baseunit logs, it appears that the “Removed from screen” message/unshare trigger caught by the button comes from the baseunit being stuck in a “waiting for stop” state.

*We need to investigate why the baseunit becomes stuck in this state*

Hi [~accountid:712020:bc98c096-e1cb-4b10-be57-46731666dcb2] , unfortunatly no, this is the same issue. I checked it using my patch I removed the DP IN connection check. In this case client app works.

With the all_logs.txt from [+https://mx.barco.com:4800/tests_details?id_list=[104836983]+|https://mx.barco.com:4800/tests_details?id_list=%5B104836983%5D]. I can see that UPSP was in sharing for a few seconds, then receiving {{compositor.unshareSource}} request from client:

{noformat}01-10 07:31:21.594  2528  6525 D UPSourceProviderJNI: [Protocol::packetReceived] Received message = {"id":7,"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"compositor.shareSource","params":{"layoutOption":"auto","sourceID":"1"}}
...
01-10 07:31:21.686  2719  2719 D StateMachine: onShareEnabled, state: DP_SHARING
01-10 07:31:21.702  2719  2719 D StateMachine: Transition from DP_SHARING to VIRTUAL_CAMERA_WAITING
01-10 07:31:22.863  2719  2719 D StateMachine: onVirtualCameraConnected, state: VIRTUAL_CAMERA_WAITING
01-10 07:31:22.891  2719  2719 D StateMachine: Transition from VIRTUAL_CAMERA_WAITING to VIRTUAL_CAMERA_SHARING
...
01-10 07:31:24.284  2528  6525 D UPSourceProviderJNI: [Protocol::packetReceived] Received message = {"id":9,"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"compositor.unshareSource","params":{"sharedSourceID":"10323025611728217935"}}
...
01-10 07:31:24.353  2719  2719 D StateMachine: onVirtualCameraDisconnected, state: VIRTUAL_CAMERA_SHARING
01-10 07:31:24.387  2719  2719 D StateMachine: onShareDisabled, state: VIRTUAL_CAMERA_SHARING, reason: UNKNOWN
01-10 07:31:24.402  2719  2719 D StateMachine: Transition from VIRTUAL_CAMERA_SHARING to DP_SHARING
{noformat}

You can see that state of Ingest service is transitioning as expected from VIRTUAL_CAMERA_SHARING back to DP_SHARING as unshared. Thus, I would suggest involving APP team in to have a look +why client sends unshare request to server while sharing (take over from DP-in sharing)+.

Hi [~accountid:5b20005bba383e08140044c2] , according to the comment below, could you please check from the Client App team side +why client sends unshare request to server while sharing (take over from DP-in sharing)+? Thanks.

From client’s log, there is an error message reported by the capturing engine, and then client stop sharing

{{Info    :  2026-01-10 08:31:25.049  : [content_source::DXGIDesktopCapture::doUpdateFrame] AcquireNextFrame failed: DXGI_ERROR_ACCESS_LOST}}

[~accountid:712020:f3a1bcc3-dd07-44e8-9067-787edd04ce9b] The client sent unshare request because it cannot capture content from the specified source (the screen might be removed) and not able to share, therefore it stopped sharing.
[~accountid:5b200055088822535508ca9b]  Hi, who is owner of scipt , we’d like to further discuss test cases.

[~accountid:630494a66acf9eeb443dcd42]  , I am the owner of this script

Please feel free to contact me
[~accountid:712020:bc98c096-e1cb-4b10-be57-46731666dcb2] According to the log, the test script tried to share a screen which would be removed later. I think we need to review the test script first.

comments.body: [~accountid:63d7851ec2b1cb6b346f3474] , something for BlueWhale to have a look at?

Created a ticket for MSI [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0667-531|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0667-531|smart-link] .

From my investigation looks like the issue is no video signal through Type-C DP output after deep sleep, despite cable detection.
After device wakes from deep sleep, Type-C cable connection is detected correctly (DP_INPUT_INSERT broadcast received), but there is no video signal transmitted through the DisplayPort output. The issue does NOT occur after full device reboot - only after deep sleep wake-up.
Looks like the HDMI ingest failure is primarily due to HDMI RX hardware and driver stack not being fully reinitialized after deep standby. HPD is detected, but no valid video/audio signal is established.

MSI is testing the firmware change as we speak
[https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0667-531?focusedCommentId=1562567|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/CS0667-531?focusedCommentId=1562567|smart-link]

fields.description:
* Hardware:
-- tested on Duvel PVT Hub Pro
* Prerequisites:
-- Base Unit version: 04.02.00.0025 Release, 04.02.00.0026 Release

      -- Vedett fw version: 3.1.0

      -- One 1080p DELL S2240T, monitor is connected to the BU via HDMI 2 port

      -- One 4K Philips monitor PHL 288P6L is connected to the BU via HDMI 1 port

      -- Vedett PVT is connected to BU.

      -- Meetup is connected over USB A port

* Steps:

# Send the BU to Deep sleep → OK
# Wake up the BU by pressing the front power button → OK
# Connect a USB C to USB C cable between a laptop that is playing a video and the BU -> Observe→ NOK

* Actual results:

# BU enters Deep sleep → OK
# BU is up and running → OK
# The HDMI 2 monitor shows only a grey screen. The content from the laptop is not displayed. Also the audio cannot be heard through the speakers. Reconnecting the cable did not solve the issue. Tested with 2 laptops and the result was the same→ NOK

Note: Issue is always reproducible after waking up from Deep sleep. 

After re-powering the BU, the issue was no longer seen.

* Expected results:

# The BU should show the content of the laptop screen on the HDMI 2 monitor.  

* Occurrence rate:
-- 3/3 attempts Issue is always reproducible after waking up from Deep sleep. 
* Fixed by:

       -- Re-power the BU.

comments.body:
Aaron feedback:

Based on Logs investigation/analysis,  You can see the limit reached banner appearing and disappearing because there's an RDP source on there that keeps failing to connect. So it starts -> limit reached -> fails to connect -> stops -> limit no longer reached. This is expected behavior on Media side end.


Next Step: decide with UX is this acceptable behavior for this situation or think about a different way how to handle notification is this particular case ( perhaps keep showing the alert x times instead of instantly closing… )

A topic for discussion to be added on the UX sync meetings

fields.description:
h3. Actual behavior

The decoding performance error flickers when a huge amount of sources are opened on a SAN.
It will appear for a very short amount of time before dissappearing (~100ms)

An initial investigation seems to point that the LayoutManager incorrectly sends an event notifying the service that the limit_reached is now false again, while the source is still saying the desk is overloaded.

SAN 1.13.0-1658

h3. Occurrence rate

We have a certain SAN with a certain layout where it happens if you open a new web source or camera source.
It properly opens when a RDP source is opened.

Reproduction on other SANs or with other sources havent been possible.
So occurrence rate is probably relatively low. 

1/10

h3. Workaround (If any)



{panel:bgColor=#deebff}
Make sure to attach relevant artifacts (logs/videos/timestamp)


{panel}

comments.body:
The setup in this situation *does not have a password policy set*.
This use case is not supported by UX or server-side.

If there are customers which have this configured, we need to figure out how the UI should handle this situation.
[~accountid:712020:a95f6402-65e9-4532-9c4c-72821fb12033] [~accountid:63d7859cfb75f8568f5e8da4]
[~accountid:63d7859cfb75f8568f5e8da4] this should be added to the release notes or a KB.

I have discussed this with [~accountid:63d7859cfb75f8568f5e8da4] and he is fine to fix this in 1.14. But this means that we should pick this up this sprint.

CC:[~accountid:63d7840482eeee78a4cd31a6] [~accountid:712020:a95f6402-65e9-4532-9c4c-72821fb12033]

[~accountid:63d7840482eeee78a4cd31a6] This setup had the password policy rules removed via the previous UI page.

Install 1.11 or earlier

Remove the password policy rules via the UI in Settings->User

Update to 1.12

Check password policy under Settings->Security or try to create a new user

Note: New users worked in 1.11
[~accountid:557058:3b704ca5-9dad-42b3-8e9f-91eaa8222485] KB created.

As discussed, from 1.14 we will in this case, automatically set the default password policy back.
We will no longer allow *no password policy* to be set.

[~accountid:63d7840482eeee78a4cd31a6] Thanks. So I understand this will also fix it for the SNMP page or other pages where the policy is used. But posting here just to double-check.

And what about accounts that don’t meet the password policy?
[~accountid:63d7840482eeee78a4cd31a6] To confirm, users with a password that does not fit the new policy will be allowed to login once you force the policy?

[~accountid:63d7859cfb75f8568f5e8da4] [~accountid:640f05c9c35660c269b9613f] 

* this will indeed also fix the SNMP page
* Password policies are applied when a user sets/resets a password and are not checked on existing credentials while logging in.
The only policy which is verified at login time is the expiration of the password.

Hopefully that clears up any concerns.

comments.body:
* Note these build erros come up during aosp build (not during apk build), at the moment the prebuilt is installed in the fs 
* The commit introducing the problem is the bump of cs-logger 0.4.3 to 1.0.5
* The build error leads to classes in BouncyCastle: see the attached verification-errors+mapping.txt: it contains the build errors, along with the corresponding mapping file.
Bouncy castle is used by cslogger to generate bug reports (though only rest-api has permission to do this)
* I bumped cslogger in order to have the package name in the logs, this was introduced in 0.5.0, so I need at least 0.5.0. 0.9.8 (same as compositor) is working too. (so I can unblock by downgrading cslogger)
* [~accountid:712020:00497842-c375-4b42-a5c4-aaade9cb679f] : do you have an idea what is happening here?

For reproducing this issue:
See attached 'build.zip' this is the build log of the RELEASE_NIGHTLY_TEST build that failed.
From that log file it seems wave4_platform_builder was at 


{noformat}commit 2b6294719c69b33cc9ecc7e3502d9cd9bc9eb222 (HEAD, tag: 04.03.00.master-1434)
Merge: 3eb173ba df9605ce
Author: Neefs, Jef <jef.neefs@barco.com>
Date:   Thu Jan 29 12:19:18 2026 +0000

    Merge pull request #1746 from barcoclickshare/shift-tests-around-for-more-efficiency
    
    feat: move reboot time test with SELinux violation check to ota test file nofota{noformat}

Then I made a release build:

{noformat}export BUILD_TYPE="release"{noformat}

You’ll see the error in the mdep part of the build

[~accountid:712020:0c99dada-2218-4d2c-a72e-2a4349ac56e6] , [~accountid:712020:7c296df2-8b16-4e65-8fab-361484289bd6]  can you take this fix also to the 4.2.0 release branch once it’s verified? [~accountid:5b30c09636e1832cfafcca06]  still needs builds from there.
Just checked with Julie: this branch still has disp mgr 0.22.0, so that build is facing another problem.

It can be time consuming to try out a candidate fix for display mgr, you built and signed locally.
I attached ‘run-lazy.sh’, I used it in the 04.03.00.master-1434 version of w4pb, so it should be directly useable.
It is the same as the official run.sh, but with a few add on’s:

* After downloading vendor, applying patches to it, contrib, …. it will create a marker file PREPARED_VENDOR
If that marker file exists it will not do this ‘prepare’ steps again (unless you specify --prepare vendor)
* It does a similar thing for mdep
* If it sees you already built vendor, it skips vendor and immediately proceeds to a truly incremental mdep build
(unless you specify --build-vendor)

So for this ticket’s use case: 

* make a full build with the run-lazy.sh script. (without options)
* build and sign (debug keys) your apk
* copy your apk in place: 
{{cp displaymanager-master-apk.apk w4duvel-build-dir/mdep/vendor/barco/prebuilt/app/display-manager-apk/display-manager-apk.apk}}
* build again using run-lazy.sh (again without options): it will immediately start building mdep and install the apk

This way I could try out say 10 apk’s in half an hour.

In case the apk is ok you’ll see:

{noformat}build.13.log:[ 21% 8/38] //vendor/barco/prebuilt/app/display-manager-apk:display-manager-apk dexpreopt [common]
build.13.log:[ 23% 9/38] Install out/target/product/mdep_kiosk_collab_arm64/system_ext/priv-app/display-manager-apk/oat/arm64/display-manager-apk.odex
build.13.log:[ 26% 10/38] Install out/target/product/mdep_kiosk_collab_arm64/system_ext/priv-app/display-manager-apk/oat/arm64/display-manager-apk.vdex{noformat}

comments.body:
[~accountid:63d78502010d3563796ff7db] 
Provided link doesn’t work and can you ask for a video?

Need some more details on the setup, how is the PC connected to the d440?
Native HDMI or DP->HDMI?

[~accountid:61fb7f7eacd4cb0069d0af29] You’re right, the first link ended up with the webpage having a typo - however sharepoint achieved to provide a broken link…

I’ll request a video and further information on the connection between the PC and D440.

They do agree that this might be related to network, given that 4:2:2 is of course increasing the network bandwidth usage.

[~accountid:63d78502010d3563796ff7db]we also faced the exact same issue when sharing a common web source — NGS‑D440 streams started flickering. Later, we found that the LAN cable was limited to 100 Mbps. After replacing the cable with a Gigabit‑supported one, the issue was resolved.

Tagging [~accountid:557058:3d792d4d-0919-4e12-bf70-fa39fe793d4f] , who recently faced the same issue

[~accountid:63d782a61b13d42998e06144] 
This could indeed be an issue as we support YUV 4:2:2 streaming in CTRL 1.12, which requires more bandwidth, but we first need to have a working link to the logs to see it’s that’s a possible culprit.
CTRL 1.12 should have correct network diagnostics: [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-26186|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-26186|smart-link] .

Mind that we have had issues before and that idea was to put the source in warning state in ctrl, but I don’t know if this has been implemented as such:
[https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-15918?focusedCommentId=1312862|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-15918?focusedCommentId=1312862|smart-link]

[~accountid:63d7859cfb75f8568f5e8da4] [~accountid:712020:8b3227a8-de06-456d-a6e1-f6507b7e0867] 
Added link to possible related ticket about network speed and how to handle < 1 Gbps in ctrlsystem: [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-15918|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-15918|smart-link] 
Seems like this ticket is at a standstill for a long time, but should be taken up to have a holistic ctrl way of handling possible too low network bandwidth.

[~accountid:61fb7f7eacd4cb0069d0af29] [~accountid:63d782a61b13d42998e06144] 


I’ve requested details on which devices we should be looking it, given there are way too many devices in that log archive.
Below is the response wrt to the video:

_Video is appx 10min before log, but the tearing appers all the time so it should not matter._

_NGS and SAN that video shows, but tearing appers on all different SAN and NGS._

[PQM] Customer is using a 1Gbps connection, so that should not be the cause. Kevin to add more info on this.
Ryan will link to another similar issue, also using 1Gbps.

Partner confirmed, they use gigabit. Customer, who reproduced the issue is also using gigabit.

_Everything is connected with 1Gbit/s network, to one Ubiquiti switch. That one is from our demokit, however customer (Kyndryl,_ [_CZ243201_|https://serviceportal.barco.com/s/projects/a5A8Y000000eFXzUAM/cz243201]_) has the same behavior. Again, connected to one Cisco switch vi gigabit network._

[~accountid:61fb7f7eacd4cb0069d0af29] 
Is customer aware that the video timing input to the ngs-d440 is actually 3840x2160@60 iso 2560x1440@60?
Are they using DP->HDMI adapters?
Are they forcing UHD timing in windows or video card driver app?
Latency outliers are also negatively impacted by having the source in focus in CTRLSystem, as that will greatly increase the rate of thumbnails requests towards the encoder, which negatively affect the scheduler.
If customer would disable interaction, which would configure the encoder to stream in normal latency, the issue should go away, can you have them test that and report back?

The reason why customer is now seeing this is probably due to YUV 4:2:2 streaming, cf. [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-30004?focusedCommentId=1555560|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-30004?focusedCommentId=1555560|smart-link]

fields.customfield_10080: We should keep 7+ days of data in the real time tables depending on table
fields.description:
Implement a mechanism to clean up the IBaseAssetUpdate, LocationUpdate, AccountUpdate tables.

E.g. “delete all records that are older than 3 days”

The data is joined between the ETL tables and the real time tables.
On the next day’s run the data in the real time tables is populated in the ETL table.
We should have a daily job that deletes records older than 7 days from the real time tables.

We want the job to be parametrized so that we have different limits for each table. We should make a control table for the real time tables to isolate it from the existing ETL flows.

* Make a control table in serve schema 
* Create pipeline to run daily
* Sync with JDM or Sulabh for scheduling via CA

comments.body:
+Open questions:+

* Implementing extreme black within dynablack limits the usage of that feature to those products that support dynablack. Is that ok or not?
* What are the expectations of PM for extreme black? Is it purely seen as a contrast improvement or also to be used for power saving purposes? E.g. if my projector has no signal and no signal pattern is set to blue than extreme black will not be usable to turn of the light source completely upon no signal detection.
* If we implement extreme black within dynamic contrast it becomes less predictable how long it takes to turn off the lasers completely upon black detection, because the time it takes dynablack to dim to minimum power depends on the histogram. (previous image contents before black) If we implement it as it used to be for lady Gaga, the maximum time it takes to turn of the lasers is defined (but the actual time may be shorter, depending on the actual laser power at the start of dimming.

Final decision was made on the implementation type, the functionality will be considered separate from dynablack.
So the user must have control over the time it takes to dim to black and shutoff and the threshold for the grey value.

fields.description:
After another deliberation session it became very apparent that the previously not required features of:

*Lights Out Timer:*
Set a timer for the laser light to turn off after detecting black content.
The set value ranges from 0s to 20s.

*Lights Out Signal Level:*
Set a black level value as the threshold for the Real Black function.
The value can be selected from 0 to 255, with 0 being the darkest black and 255 being the brightest.

Are hard requirements.

----

This fights with the current design, where it is not transparent to the user how long it will take for the shutter to close once black content starts arriving.
As the time till shutter would depend on the current “level of dimming“. Additionally it was noted that the current dynblack is very slow and so it would take a long time to take effect.

Can we design a system that allows both, or perhaps we can adapt the originally provided system to allow for forcing shutter of when dynablack ?

{noformat}SPFlashToolV6.exe -c format-download -f "C:\XXXX\download_agent\flash.xml"{noformat}

* download                                                         
* format-download

* read-efuse                                                         
* download-cert

SPFlashToolV6.exe -c download -f flash.xml

Demo from EIS team: [EIS Sprint Review-20250227_153224-Meeting Recording.mp4|https://barcozone-my.sharepoint.com/:v:/r/personal/toshivibhor_aeron_barco_com/Documents/Recordings/EIS%20Sprint%20Review-20250227_153224-Meeting%20Recording.mp4?csf=1&web=1&e=zE93HL&nav=eyJyZWZlcnJhbEluZm8iOnsicmVmZXJyYWxBcHAiOiJTdHJlYW1XZWJBcHAiLCJyZWZlcnJhbFZpZXciOiJTaGFyZURpYWxvZy1MaW5rIiwicmVmZXJyYWxBcHBQbGF0Zm9ybSI6IldlYiIsInJlZmVycmFsTW9kZSI6InZpZXcifSwicGxheWJhY2tPcHRpb25zIjp7InN0YXJ0VGltZUluU2Vjb25kcyI6NzczLjMyfX0%3D]

Useful links: [https://iot-cidrelease.cmp.barco.cloud/configuration-service/docs#/|https://iot-cidrelease.cmp.barco.cloud/configuration-service/docs#/]

[~accountid:5af5ecb7be64530a4d5c49f0] , [~accountid:712020:b0536461-cec5-43b7-aae6-9d50bb83eda3]  a bit surprised we are going this way without having refined the architecture around logging. Know that there are many restrictions and remarks from security side around this and that this should be refined and made uniform for all apk’s… There is a whole initiative around that… What is the idea of this story?

Also, logcat is considered insecure so this part of the story will and should be removed anyway later on. Even if it’s a temporary measure to upload to xms already.
[~accountid:61eaca1254627a00708d90eb] we noticed we have quite some dependencies still, so we’ll split this task up.
[~accountid:5af5ecb7be64530a4d5c49f0]  is this another example of left-over promised refactor that never gets done? 😕

[~accountid:61eaca1254627a00708d90eb] No, this is planned work. Once we are done with migrating Iot-Agent to CS-Logger instead of Timber, we have to refactor the current impementation of getLogs, in its current form, it does not send the actual correct logs to iothub/xms.

At the time of original implementation logging epic was not yet done, so we had to create a temporary solution that grabs the logs of only iot-agent and uploads them.

That was originally agreed upon as a placeholder until the logging epic was further fleshed out and the correct implementation could be made.
This would have been done/planned much earlier, but while we were working on the migration to cs-logger. that got descoped in favor of higher priority epic → We are now picking this logging epic back up in january
Current status: on the platform builder merge queue and will soon be ready for verification (as part of subtask CS0666-8509).
Changes will be available starting from master build 1460

Tested master-1464 test build and confirmed with Bjarne that we need to wait for [https://github.com/barcoclickshare/wave4-platform-builder/pull/2228|https://github.com/barcoclickshare/wave4-platform-builder/pull/2228|smart-link]  before validating, since as for now the Getlog is not working properly and we get an error. 

!image-20260210-144823.png|width=651,alt="image-20260210-144823.png"!

We need to wait for the PR to be merged in wave4 platform builder to validate.

fields.description:
It makes sense to check the NMS license to enable/disable certain functionality, but you should always be able to at least log in with a valid user, so that for example you can change certificates, no matter the license.

- You need to be able to log in without NMS
- When you go to video routing page/audio routing page/devices page/diagnostics, ideally it is clear that NMS is down, but whatever is easiest, but in any case, it “shouldn’t” go wrong.
- MCC300 page goes via the device manager

Technical suggestion:

* the front-end stores whether NMS is up or down (can use websocket event, an API is useful for first time check?)
* the pages mentioned above can be wrapped and in the case of NMS down, a simple component which just has some text “NMS is down” can be shown, avoiding that all the components do their queries
* if it 's difficult at the side of NMS: device manager could intervene in the proxy?

fields.description:
We considered 2 approaches to fetch the schema, personally i would opt for option 1:

# Add specs repo as a git submodule 

* Pro
** Fine grained control over version + dependabot can automatically open PRs for bumps
** Recommended by devops
** Easy to develop with local changes to schemas
* Con
** Clutter the repo
** add dependency to {{barcoemu}} for clone?

# Clone specs repo during gradle build

* Pro
** No maintaining submodule, automatically takes latest master from specs
* Con
** No fine grained control over versioning or easy way to change schema locally for development
** Build requires git access to {{barcoemu}}

{quote}Hi MTK team,

I have tried to flash Duvel using the latest SP flash tool, v.5.2548.00.
However, it says that the DA does not match.
​It seems that the SP flash tool DLL’s validation of instructions sent to the MTK SoC via DA may be causing an incorrect hash issue.

Noted that the same DA works on v.5.2444.00, but not on v.5.2548.00 (was using the factory material from master-1378).

Thanks
Chanel{quote}

fields.description:
When we try to flash Duvel with v5.2548 (which is the latest version), it says that the DA does not match.

!image-20260210-130552.png|width=319,alt="image-20260210-130552.png"!

Looks like the DA binary needs to be updated to be used on v5.2548.00.

The same DA works on v.5.2444.00, but not on v.5.2548.00 (was using the factory material from master-1378)



adding more info:

the SP flash tool version MTK created are v1.2444 (2025 ver) and v1.2548 (2026 ver)

and in those versions, you can find V5 and V6

for example, in the v1.2444 version, you can find v5.2444 (for duvel) and v6.2444 (for GOD)

comments.body:
h2. Commit 1

PRJ0666-20802: PP - Fix memory leaks and FormControl error in Console Component

# The console input field was incorrectly using both {{formControlName="jsonrpc"}} and {{[formControl]="jsonRpcFormControl"}} simultaneously: {{<input formControlName="jsonrpc" [formControl]="jsonRpcFormControl" />}}. Angular's forms system doesn't allow mixing these two directives:

* {{formControlName}} requires a parent {{[formGroup]}} directive and looks up the control by string name.
* {{[formControl]}} is for standalone form controls with direct instance binding.
This caused Angular to throw runtime errors every time the component was initialized.
Solved by removing invalid {{formControlName="jsonrpc"}} attribute, keeping only {{[formControl]="jsonRpcFormControl"}}.

# Unmanaged subscriptions (memory leaks): two subscriptions were created without proper cleanup:

* {{this.consoleService.logEventEmitter.subscribe(l => {this.updateLog()})}}
* {{this.dialogService.showConfirm(...).subscribe(result => {if (result === true) {this.consoleService.clear()}})}}
Each time the Console component was created (e.g., during navigation or user switching), new subscriptions were registered but never cleaned up when the component was destroyed.

The codebase uses a {{SubscriptionCleaner}} base class (located in {{SubscriptionCleaner.ts}}) to handle subscription lifecycle management:

* Components/services extend {{SubscriptionCleaner}}
* Use {{this.subscribe(observable, callback)}} instead of {{observable.subscribe(callback)}}
* The helper method automatically applies {{takeUntilDestroyed()}} operator
* Angular's {{DestroyRef}} detects component/service destruction
* All subscriptions are automatically unsubscribed on cleanup
* No need for manual {{ngOnDestroy()}} or subscription tracking
This pattern is already used extensively throughout the codebase (20+ components including MainComponent, BlendAndMaskService, ShutterControlButtonComponent, etc.).

All subscriptions on the Console component now automatically clean up when the component is destroyed, preventing memory leaks.

fields.description:
I discovered this while working on the MCC300. I used 127.0.0.1 as IP for the devicemanager → nms communication. This results in an SSL Handshake error at devicemanager side, since 127.0.0.1 is not in the SAN of NMS.

Assuming NMS is running on 192.168.1.243 (internal Nexxis network). So that SAN will have that IP. If it goes through the copper of the hospital network (let's say 10.10.8.20) to 10.10.8.20:8443 via an integrator application, it will get an SSL handshake error (10.10.8.20 is not in the SAN).

To tackle this, NMS will need to accept a list of IP’s/Hosts.
